page.title: 08Local History
page.content: Three factors have shaped Three Bridges, the river Mole, the Railway,and Crawley new town. The name Three Bridges came from the three bridges that crossedthe river between Crawley and Worth.In 1795 Three Bridges was forest,the trees were felled for agriculture and to provide charcoal for nearby iron furnaces. In 1840 this was still an agricultural area but included a smithy,the Plough Inn and a flour mill.1841 saw the arrival of the railway and as a result the population inreased considerably. By 1916 there were 20 shops and 3 public houses. In 1947 Three Bridges became part of Crawley new town but many of the old names managed to survive in modern street names e.g. Scallows, Hazelwick andPriors. Local employment is nowindustrial and commercial.
